Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Campus Compute Cooperative (CCC) Planning Grant Proposal

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The idea of sharing resources between institutions is not new and has been relatively successful in a few instances and largely unsuccessful in many cases. This proposal elaborates a plan to construct the Campus Compute Cooperative (CCC), a shared cyberinfrastructure as well as a social fabric; both computational resources and support staff expertise will be pooled and shared. The CCC will: i) connect and federate campus physical infrastructures; ii) use market-based mechanisms for resource allocation and quality of service to avoid the tragedy of the commons; iii) leverage InCommon and local identity management systems to provide integrated cross-institution authentication and access control of resources; iv) facilitate secure data and storage sharing between institutions and research labs; v) offer "cloud bursting" to member institutions; and, vi) provide paid-for, differentiated quality of service.

The impact of on-demand, pay-per-use (cloud) resources on society has been huge. Making the most of limited resources is critical to the success of the nation's research enterprise. By rationally and securely sharing the limited computational and human resources available for research the CCC will both accelerate discovery and provide a research cyberinfrastructure with better cost/benefit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Campus Compute Cooperative is a socio-technical arrangement between the universities which make up its membership that allows scientific researchers to use computing resources at any of the member institutions.  The software supporting the cooperative allows researchers to submit computing jobs to the cooperative without needing to specify where they will run, only what hardware requirements the job has. The members of the cooperative exchange work based on this steering of jobs between institutions, on a market-based model that allows universities to reconcile any imbalances with a periodic cost recovery based on agreed-upon pricing.

This model for exchange of resources between institution allows researchers to access computing resources that are larger than they might otherwise have access to, or for types of resources that are not available at researches' home institution. Researchers at member institutions are able to access a wider range of resources and larger all-over capacity, thanks to the cooperation between the member institutions. This allows researchers at institutions with different levels of resources additional access to computational resources, speeding up their work and allowing them to make discoveries that they would otherwise not be able to. This also allows researchers at smaller institutions with fewer resources to gain access and learn about advanced computational sciences.

The market exchange model allows work to find appropriate pricing for completing research analyses based on demand and supply of resources. This market model allows participating institutions to leverage unused capacity and to ensure their resources are well-used, and recoup some of the cost of running the systems when exchanges go unbalanced.

The Campus Compute Cooperative Team, over the life of the project, convened to create governance and exchange pricing for the cooperative, recruited shareholder institutions, and prepared a proposal to the NSF to create and fund the governing body and administration for the cooperative and fund resources for use throughout the cooperative membership. Further work to coordinate with stakeholders and initial modeling of the exchange of resources between institutions based on initial usage of the cooperative member systems with sample computational workflows.
